review.title: Machine Learning Approach for Detection of nonTor Traffic
review.abstract: Intrusion detection has attracted a considerable interest from researchers and industries. After many years of research the community still faces the problem of building reliable and efficient intrusion detection systems (IDS) capable of handling large quantities of data with changing patterns in real time situations. The Tor network is popular in providing privacy and security to end user by anonymising the identity of internet users connecting through a series of tunnels and nodes. This work focuses on the classification of Tor traffic and nonTor traffic to expose the activities within Tor traffic that minimizes the protection of users. A study to compare the reliability and efficiency of Artificial Neural Network and Support vector machine in detecting nonTor traffic in UNB-CIC Tor Network Traffic dataset is presented in this paper. The results are analysed based on the overall accuracy, detection rate and false positive rate of the two algorithms. Experimental results show that both algorithms could detect nonTor traffic in the dataset. A hybrid Artificial neural network proved a better classifier than SVM in detecting nonTor traffic in UNB-CIC Tor Network Traffic dataset.
histories: 6 pages, 4 figures, Accepted and Presented in ARES '17 Proceedings of the 12th International Conference on Availability, Reliability and Security
review.COMMENTS: 6 pages, 4 figures, Accepted and Presented in ARES '17 Proceedings of the 12th International Conference on Availability, Reliability and Security

sections.heading: 2 INTRUSION DETECTION SYSTEM
sections.text: Intrusion Detection System is a software application or device placed in strategic locations on a network to monitor and detect anomalies in network traffic [1] [2], as shown in Fig. 1. The main characteristics of IDS are to sound the alarm when an anomaly is detected. A complementary approach is to take corrective action when anomalies are detected, such an approach is referred to as the Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) [3]. Based on the interactivity characteristic of IDS, it can be designed to work either on-line or offline. Online IDS operates in a network in real time by analyzing traffic packages and classifying rules analogous to traffic. Offline IDS operates by storing data and after processing to classify normal and anomaly.

sections.heading: 3 UNB-CIC TOR NETWORK TRAFFIC DATASET
sections.text: The UNB-CIC Tor Network Traffic Dataset [17] is a representative data set of real traffic defined as a task. Three users were set up to record browser traffic and two users to record communication parts such as chat, mail, P2P, etc. from more than 18 representative applications such as Facebook, Skype, Spotify, Gmail, etc. The dataset contains 8 types of Tor traffic, as shown in Table 1, and non-Tor traffic.

sections.heading: 4.1 Artificial Neural Network
sections.text: Artificial neural network (ANN) consists of information processing elements known to mimic neurons in the brain. In this experiment, the neural network, which is a multi-layer perceptron (MLP), is equipped with a set of labeled training packages that learn to associate input characteristics listed in Table II with outputs (Tor and NonTor). Figure 2 assumes that it is a categorical variable consisting of some infinite input / output pairs.

sections.heading: 5 EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS ANALYSIS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.1 Results Evaluation Metrics
sections.text: The effectiveness of IDS requires high accuracy, a high recall rate and a high positive predictive value (precision), as well as a low false positive rate. The performance of IDS in general is evaluated in terms of overall accuracy, detection rate and false positive rate. Accuracy (ACC) = BRBRSB, STRST, detection rate (DR) = BR BRSTR False positive rate (FPR) = TR TRSB, positive predictive value (PPV) = BR BRSTR Where, true negatives (TN): a measure of the number of normal events that are rightly classified as normal. True Positives (TP): a measure of attacks that are rightly classified as attack.False Positive (FP): a measure of normal events that are classified as attack.False Negative (FN): a measure of attacks that are classified as normal.

sections.heading: 5.2 Feature Selection Algorithm
sections.text: This paper proposes Correlation-based feature selection (CFS) to select the relevant features from the 28 characteristics. CFS is a filtering algorithm that uses a correlation-based heuristic evaluation function to rank feature parts. A good set of features is strongly correlated with the class (target) and at the same time not correlated with each other. Redundant features are ignored because they have a low correlation with the class and transform into a high correlation with one or more of the remaining characteristics. A feature is accepted based on the extent to which it predicts classes in areas of the instance space that were not predicted by other characteristics. Equation (8) shows the CFS feature enhancement function. V = MWXYMSM MZ2 WYY (5) Where V is heuristically "merit" of a feature group that contains features that contain features is the average feature class.

sections.heading: 5.3 Experimental Results
sections.text: The classification of neural networks and support vectors consists of two phases: the classification phase and the training phase, as shown in Fig. 3. In the training phase, the algorithm learns the distribution of characteristics with corresponding classes. During the classification phase, the learned model is applied to a test set that the training phase has not seen before. In this thesis, the experiment was trained by training ANN and SVM with UNB-CIC Tor Network Traffic datasets to detect non-gate traffic. In the first set of the experiment, ANN was trained with all 28 characteristics of the data set with 20-hidden neurons and with 10 characteristics selected with CFS with 6-hidden nodes. ANN uses Levenberg-Marquardt Training Function (trainlm) for learning. In the second set of the experiment, ANN was trained with all 28 characteristics of the data set with 20-hidden neurons and with 10 characteristics were evaluated by CANS, using the data set with 4.S and FM were selected.

sections.heading: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: This work focuses mainly on the detection of non-Tor traffic in a representative dataset of real traffic in order to detect activities within Tor traffic that reduce user privacy. It proposes a CFS-ANN hybrid classifier for detecting non-Tor traffic in the UNB-CIC Tor Network Traffic dataset. Experimental results show that the proposed NonTor algorithm detects with an accuracy of 99.8%, a detection rate of 100% and a false positive rate of 1.2%. The proposed algorithm works better than SVM and C4.5 in [7], as shown in Table 4. The proposed hybrid classifier reduces the dimensionality of the data size by 65% by removing the less effective features, thereby reducing calculation costs and training time.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
sections.text: The authors thank the Canadian Institute of Cyber Security, University of Brunswick, for providing the dataset to carry out this work.

referenceMentions.context: Tor which is popular in fighting internet censorship has been deployed to serve thousands of users transferring terabytes of data daily [1], [2].
Tor which is popular in fighting internet censorship has been deployed to serve thousands of users transferring terabytes of data daily [1], [2].
A user browses the web firstly by sending a request anonymously to Tor routers from one of the directory servers [2], [3].
A user browses the web firstly by sending a request anonymously to Tor routers from one of the directory servers [2], [3].
A session key is then generated between the client and the Entry Guard using Deffie-Hellman key exchange [4].
The last hop called the exit router communicates direct with the destination as a proxy [1].
The design of TOR network which includes the use of three hops and session keys helps to maintain anonymity through a concept called ‘perfect forward secrecy’[2], [5].
Tor networks are created to give internet users their privacy, freedom of speech, illegal tapping traffic and surveillance of network threatening users’ personal identity [6].
Besides Tor network being used for good, greater portion of its traffic are port scans, hacking attempts, exfiltration of stolen data and online criminality [2].
Over the last decade, Tor traffic classification has advanced in its applications in systems like quality of service (QoS) tools or Security information and Event management (SIEM) [7].
A considerable interest have been attracted from researchers and the industries to the study of these technologies and developing classification techniques [8][7].

Most IDs employ a signature based detection approach where the network traffic is monitored and compared against database rules or signature of known anomaly in network traffic [9][10].
Most IDs employ a signature based detection approach where the network traffic is monitored and compared against database rules or signature of known anomaly in network traffic [9][10].
Although it is effective in detecting known anomalies, it cannot detect unknown anomalies unless the signature and rules are updated with new signatures [11][12].
Although it is effective in detecting known anomalies, it cannot detect unknown anomalies unless the signature and rules are updated with new signatures [11][12].
Signature based is known to have a significant time lapse between anomaly detection and activation of its corresponding signature [10].
It observes changes in normal activity of network traffic and builds a profile of the network traffic being monitored [13][14].
It observes changes in normal activity of network traffic and builds a profile of the network traffic being monitored [13][14].
However outlier detection based IDS have the disadvantage of being computational expensive because the profile generated over a period needs to be updated against each system activity [15] [10].
